WHAT'S CHANGEDMphasiS Limited (MBFL.NS)FromToPrice TargetRs3,500.00Rs3,625.00

Micro factors appear to be aligning for MphasiS and any macro support from rate cuts could provide further tailwinds to growth. Chasing growth within FCF margin guardrails creates re- . rating potential. MphasiS is our preferred mid- cap play.
Coming off a bad cycle, we expect MphasiS to enter a beat and raise revenue trajectory.
Improving growth trends create re- rating potential; we expect the stock to narrow the valuation gap with mid- cap peers as the revenue growth gap narrows.
We think investors should look to double down on the future potential event of a promoter stake sale rather than wait for that to be an entry point.

Breakout candidate: Fundamentals are improving for MphasiS. We see multiple catalysts for a potential re- rating if it continues to execute well: 1) consistent pipeline growth; 2) the size of quarterly deal wins inching up from a run rate of US \(\) 300- 400\(mn (especially if driven outside of the BFSI vertical), and the rising conversion of deal wins to revenue; 3) potential revenue diversification outside the top 10 clients and BFSI (e.g., in Healthcare); 4) consistent rate cuts, potentially lifting DR revenue; and 5) majority stakeholder's potential sale of entire stake over the next 2- 3 years (an event that helped Coforge re- rate in 2023). We raise our revenue growth estimates 50bps for F27 (to 13.2%) and 100bps for F28 (to 11%).

Growth vs. margin conundrum: The confluence of macro volatility and new technology is changing demand patterns - up- front investment may be required for companies to stay relevant. MphasiS is chasing growth while defining guardrails in the form of an OCF- to PAT ratio of at least 80% (vs. 100%+ previously). We find this a prudent way to balance the quantity and quality of revenue growth.

How to think about valuation: Looking at relevant mid- cap valuations relative to revenue growth, the group trades between 2x and 3.5x (P/E on F27e EPS over F25- 27e organic revenue CAGR), with MphasiS toward the bottom end of this range. We also draw parallels with IT Services in terms of the way investors look at software stocks and argue that as long as guardrails are defined in the business, growth should be given more weight over FCF margins. Our new price target for MphasiS implies 30x Sep- 25e EPS (2.9x P/E/revenue CAGR).

Increasing TAM by aggressively participating in managed services deals and focusing on large deals is leading to consistent upturn in the qualified deal pipeline. The revenue base is largely flat (vs. three years ago) while the qualified pipeline is up 3- 4x, by our estimates.

Our calculations indicate increasing conversion of pipeline to deal TCV (Total Contract Value) and increasing conversion of deal TCV to revenue, especially given that vertical- specific challenges appear to be behind the company.
MphasiS also remains a rate cut beneficiary, with digital risk revenues at a low point in the cycle.

Historically, MphasiS has done well on client mining and has shown capability to scale clients at levels much higher than other mid- cap peers. Diversification outside of the top 10 clients and outside of the BFSI/TMT verticals (especially in Healthcare) bode well for MphasiS.
These factors make us believe that MphasiS has the potential to narrow the revenue growth gap to other mid- cap peers.

If we analyse the way investors look at software companies or SaaS business models globally (either using the Rule of 40, the Weighted Rule of 40 or the Rule of X), we notice that growth is given higher weight (like 2- 3x vs. FCF margins) or at least an equal weight (vs. FCF margins), depending on the stage of growth and margin profile.

We draw parallels with IT Services, and argue that a higher growth profile should more than offset a lower FCF margin profile (if we apply this in the case of MphasiS, even after investments, FCF margins would be in line with or better than some of the other mid- caps), leading to re- rating of the stock.

Cooking at P on a relative basis, over the last five years MBFL has traded at an average discount of \(17\%\) to LTIM and at best at a premium of \(12\%\) . However, during that time, it lagged in terms of growth vs. LTIM – which we see changing. We expect MBFL to generate stronger revenue growth than LTIM over F25- 27, which we think could lead the stock to trade at a premium to LTIM.

Our EPS estimates are largely similar to consensus; however, we have much stronger conviction in revenue growth rates for MphasiS than consensus does, even though our margin assumptions are lower. We think consensus is underestimating the revenue growth potential despite delivery on pipeline and deal wins. We expect above- consensus revenue growth assumptions to also lead to re- rating of the stock, thereby providing strong returns.
- Deal wins surprise over 2Q/3Q vs. expectations of US\$40mn+.- Revenue growth accelerates in 2HF26, driven by deal win surprises and increasing conversion of deal wins to revenue.

Increasing TAM and focus on large deals is leading to consistent upturn in qualified deal pipeline. Our calculations indicate increasing conversion of pipeline to deal TCV and increasing conversion of deal TCV to revenue, given that vertical- specific challenges are behind. Historically, MphasiS has done well on client mining and has shown capability to scale clients at levels much higher than other mid cap peers. MphasiS also remains a rate cut beneficiary with DR revenues at a low point in the cycle. These factors make us believe that MphasiS has the potential to narrow the growth gap with other mid cap peers.

MphasiS has been reporting strong qoq and yoy upturn in qualified pipeline over the past several quarters despite registering strong deal wins. Also, in our estimates, while the revenue base has remained largely similar over the last three years, the qualified deal pipeline has become 3- 4x over the same time period, implying potential for strong growth rated. We cite the following reasons for this:

- MphasiS has increased the intensity with which it is engaging with third-party deal advisors, which has increased its deal pipeline funnel, even though that could also be shifting the mix of pipeline towards RFQ (Request for Quotation) led deals vs. proactive deals previously.- MphasiS was largely participating in deals geared towards application development while lagging on managed services deals, where it was finding it difficult to compete with larger peers. With the introduction of AI platforms such as NeoZeta and NeoCrux, its offerings are now becoming comparable to some of the larger-cap peers, and it is able to participate in cost takeout managed services deals. This is also reflected in an increasing proportion of fixed price projects in its revenue mix.

Following our upgrade of MphasisS from EW to OW (see here: Four reasons to be constructive; upgrade to Ow), we faced pushback from clients on two key aspects that are causing investor uncertainty: 1) use of balance sheet for growth and 2) potential for promoter to sell out through a block. While we outline our thoughts below, we think uncertainty offers a good entry point and could lead to robust stock price returns if our thesis were to play out.

Changing nature of demand: The confluence of macro volatility and emerging use of new technology is changing demand patterns. Macro volatility has led to a lack of growth in client budgets and clients are more inclined to do more with less; hence, we have seen a proliferation of cost takeout projects. At the same time, the advent of new technology has become a topic of boardroom discussions and the realization of up- front savings has become front of mind for senior executives.
From a vendor perspective, we see three options to address this change:

Calibrated use of the balance sheet may be required to stay relevant in front of clients: Use of the balance sheet has been reflected in higher contract costs and/or unbilled receivables, particularly in select mid-caps; this has been a cause of debate, most recently in the case of MphasisS. Contract costs have been defined as incremental costs of obtaining a contract and costs incurred in fulfilling a contract with customers and are amortized over the term of the contract. These costs are included in the balance sheets of most IT companies and are amortized over the period of contract there as well (so the principle remains the same). We note that the costs may be 1- 2% of revenues for some companies, while select mid-caps have seen a surge in these costs as a percentage of their revenue base.

We think that the increase in contract costs is a function of mid- caps now participating in many larger deals than most players in the industry (at their size), reflecting the higher revenue growth profile of these companies. So, in a way, it could be construed as a cost of winning market share.
Exhibit 9: Contract costs (as a percentage of revenue) – While the line item appears on most company balance sheets, select mid-caps have shown a surge in contract costs
Source: Company data, Morgan Stanley Research estimates

Capitalization removes volatility from the margin profile: Vendors have up- front transition costs to bear, especially when taking over from an existing vendor, which are now further escalated by an expectation to pass on up- front savings by clients. Capitalization of such costs on the balance sheet and subsequent amortization reduces volatility in the margin profile, where otherwise near- term margins would have been subdued and medium- term margins would increase (see illustration below). If a company were to expense everything through the P&L, implied valuation multiples on the stock 2- 3 years out would appear artificially lower (owing to higher margins then) and may not be fully representative of the company's financial position.
Exhibit 10: MphasiS: Illustrative example of a large deal, which shows a smooth margin profile on an accrual basis but a volatile margin profile on a cash basis

1. How a company knows where to draw the line with respect to how many contracts it can take onto its balance sheet at any one time; and/or 
2. The risks associated with such contracts.

1. We understand that such contracts typically have a termination fee in the event the contract is ended prematurely, and this helps alleviate some of the up-front costs undertaken by the vendor. Also, the savings promised on the contracts in subsequent years are dependent on client readiness in those years. If the client is not ready, the prior year's contract value applies.

2. In any business, there are trade-offs between growth and margins (FCF margins in this case). Hence, it is important to define guardrails around margins in the quest for growth for investors to have clarity as to what to expect in future as well. We think MphasiS's conversion of PAT to FCF is healthy (see exhibit below) and hence at a healthy FCF margin profile, it may make sense to push down on the growth pedal. In term of operating cash flow (OCF), MphasiS converts 100%+ of PAT to OCF, which it does not expect to fall below 80-85% even while chasing growth.
Exhibit 11: MphasiS - Healthy FCF profile and PAT conversion to FCF
Source: Company data, Morgan Stanley Research

Exploring the Rule of 4O/ Weighted Rule of 4O/ Rule of X to think about valuation: Globally, if we examine the way investors look at software companies or SaaS business models, whether through the Rule of 4O, the Weighted Rule of 4O, or the Rule of X, we notice that growth is given at least an equal weighting (vs. FCF margins) or a higher weighting (2- 3x vs. FCF margins), depending on the company's stage of growth and margin profile.

The Rule of 4O states that a company's revenue growth rate plus its margin should equal or exceed \(40\%\) to be considered healthy and sustainable, in effect it assigns similar weights to revenue growth and margins (allowing high- growth companies to be unprofitable and more mature, profitable companies to grow more slowly). The Weighted Rule of 4O is a variation of the standard Rule of 4O and reflects that growth is more valuable for smaller or earlier- stage companies. The Rule of X = (Growth Rate \\* Multiplier) + FCF Margin (for late- stage cloud companies, revenue growth should be weighted 2- 3x more than FCF margin when assessing valuation).

If we were to draw parallels from these rules in the case of MphasiS, for valuation multiples to be sustained, growth pickup should be in line with FCF margins coming off in percentage terms (if we were to assign similar weights to growth and margins), while multiples could expand with increasing weights towards growth, especially if the pickup in growth is much faster than FCF margins coming off.

We have seen, with Coforge and Persistent (Not Covered) as examples, that despite low FCF margins, the market assigns a higher valuation to both stocks given their growth leadership, implying a higher implied weighting given to growth vs. FCF margins.
Exhibit 12: Rule of X across scenarios indicates that the outcome in the bull case can be disproportionately high
Source: Morgan Stanley Research estimates

We think anticipation of such an event does create an overhang on the stock. Having said that, we believe the promoter group has been tactical in its approach in the past and hence a partial or full stake sale can't be ruled out.

- PE funds typically have a fund life of 10 years and a particular asset within that is typically held for 5-7 years.- Based on that assumption, investors think (based on our conversations with them) that complete selling out of stake (close to 40%) should happen by F27-28 (given that this fund invested in 2021).- Also, given that the stake is large, it might not happen in one go, but in at least a couple of tranches – which makes F26 a potential year for such one tranche.
We believe we are entering a zone where the company's positive fundamentals are moving ahead of this technical factor...
...and one should look to double down now rather than wait for a possible future event to make an entry point, in our view.

- In 2016, Blackstone acquired a controlling stake (60.47%) in MphasiS from HP Enterprise for US\$827mn (Rs430 per share).- In 2018, Blackstone sold \(\sim 8\%\) of that stake in MphasiS at Rs926 per share, while still maintaining the majority stake in the company.- In 2020, Blackstone added 4.01% to its stake in MphasiS at an average price of Rs696 per share, when the stock corrected owing to the uncertainty caused by the onset of Covid-19.

- When the fund's life was nearing its end, Blackstone further committed to MphasiS by purchasing a stake with a new fund along with co-investors (sovereign and pension funds).- In 2024, Blackstone sold \(\sim 15\%\) of its stake in MphasiS at \(\sim \mathrm{Rs}2,350 / \mathrm{share}\) , leading to the remaining stake sitting with a promoter group at \(39.58\%\) (vs. \(55.45\%\) previously).

"Blackstone first invested in this company in 2016. Even at that time we believed that MphasiS will be a 10- to 15- year growth story, not the typical 4 to 5 years. So, we are super excited that this investment enables us to continue the value creation agenda for a long term." - Mr. Amit Dixit, Senior Managing Director, Head of Asia for Blackstone Private Equity, 26th April 2021, Analyst call hosted by MPHL

"A typical Blackstone fund is raised for a period of 10 years. So, the funds which are buying into it, they are also 10- year funds. So, overall you should assume a 7- to 10- year life of these funds now going forward into the future. Plus the co- investors who are coming in, as I mentioned, they don't have a fund structure. They are sovereign and pension funds, so technically their life is infinite" - Mr. Amit Dixit, Senior Managing Director, Head of Asia for Blackstone Private Equity, 26th April 2021, Analyst call hosted by MPHL.

The company reported in 1QF26 that despite registering record- high deal wins, it attained its highest qualified deal pipeline on record and showed a QoQ increase of \(16\%\) . This implies that the pipeline increased on a gross basis much more rapidly than outflows from the pipeline (including wins and losses). We define the win ratio as deal wins in the quarter divided by deal outflow (wins + losses). We make certain assumptions around the win ratio and QoQ net additions in the pipeline under various scenarios to see how the pipeline conversion- to- deal win TCV has evolved over the past several quarters.
Scenario 1: Assuming 50% win ratio in 1QF26 and QoQ net additions to pipeline of US \(\) 500mn\$
Scenario 2: Assuming 60% win ratio in 1QF26 and QoQ net additions to pipeline of US \(\) 700mn\$
Scenario 3: Assuming 70% win ratio in 1QF26 and QoQ net additions to pipeline of US \(\) 1,000mn\$

Our scenario analysis indicates that despite strong expansion of the pipeline, after which one would expect the pipeline conversion to deal with TCV to come off, the metric has started to increase over the last three quarters. We cite two reasons for this:

- There is a lot of focus internally on large deals and a formal process has been developed, involving active participation from delivery teams and solution architects, among others.- Under the leadership of Mike Meyer (who was hired as Head of Strategic Sales in November 2024), the company is focusing a lot more on placing a winning bid by being competitive, vs. being solutions-focused previously.
Exhibit 22: Mphasis: Our scenario analysis indicates that despite expansion of its pipeline, the pipeline conversion to deal with TCV has started to strengthen after being weak for a few quarters
Source: Company data, Morgan Stanley Research estimates

Assuming a deal tenure of 4- 5 years, depending on the number and size of large deals signed in a quarter, and adjusting for drag from logistics verticals as well as no- strategic India- based ATM businesses recently, our calculations suggest that the deal win conversion to revenue is increasing for Mphasis, whether we consider one quarter or a two- quarter lag in deal TCV conversion to revenue. This could result in quarterly growth cadence increasing for Mphasis.

The company has faced multiple challenges in the past three years, many in the top 10 client bucket, which led to a decrease in the contribution of top 10 clients revenue to overall revenue over the last several quarters. At the same time, revenues from non- top 10 clients held up well, driven by a focus on diversifying the revenue base outside of BFS (53% of revenues as of 1QF26) and outside of top 10 clients (54% of revenues as of 1QF26).

With respect to the pipeline, we estimate that close to 60% of the current pipeline is driven by non- BFS verticals and close to 70% of the pipeline could be driven by non- top 10 clients - evidence in our view that the company's efforts in this direction are working.

The logistics vertical has been a drag on revenues for the past few quarters, and came off sharply in 1QF26 (now \(6\%\) of revenue vs. \(14\%\) in 1QF25; annualized revenue fell US \(120m in the quarter from its recent peak). Management has said it thinks the worst could be behind it for this vertical. For the three years prior, other challenges surfaced owing to macro volatility that kept revenue growth in check, including client- specific issues, the DXC channel's revenue run rate coming off, and the mortgage business declining in response to consistent rate increases.

We have been moderating our revenue growth assumptions for most companies we cover over the past several quarters, including for MphasiS, which appear to be changing from 1QF26, where we increased our growth assumptions.

Historically, MphasiS has been able to convert clients from one revenue bucket to a higher bucket size at a better rate compared to other mid- cap peers. Of interest, four mid- caps listed in the exhibit below have a similar revenue run rate and similar number of clients in the US\)10mn+ bucket – but when it comes to scaling these accounts beyond a certain threshold, MphasiS has had greater success (six clients in the US\)75mn+ bucket vs. three or four for others).
Recently, MphasiS highlighted that it was able to ramp up a couple of new accounts that it signed into the US\)50M+ accounts category.
Exhibit 29: Client mining: Most mid-caps on a similar revenue scale have a similar number of US\(10mn+ clients, but MphasiS has been able to scale more clients to a higher revenue bucket
Source: Company reports, Morgan Stanley Research (e) estimates. Note: 1QF26 reported numbers

"Our client pyramid continues to improve across the board: YoY we have added one client in US\)10mn+, two clients in US\)75mn+, two clients in US\)50mn+ and one client in US\)20mn+ categories. We have successfully ramped up a couple of new accounts we signed recently into the US\)50mn+ accounts category."

Historically, digital risk business revenues have been volatile and dependent on interest rate movements because the majority of the business was driven by volumes originating from the mortgage business, which increase when interest rates are lower and vice versa.

MphasiS has tried to diversify the business profile away from origination towards other lines of business - such as foreclosures, where volumes increase when interest rates increase - and hence sought relative stability for the revenue profile. However, we estimate that even after such diversification, DR revenues came off from a peak quarterly run rate of US\)75mn to US\)25mn in the past few quarters, registering a 66% drop from peak revenues in this business.
Having said that, we believe DR revenues are at a low point in the cycle and with the potential for rate cuts, the business could provide growth tailwinds over the course of the next 2- 3 years.

Why has MphasiS traded at a discount to peers in the past? We think the possible reasons are as follows:

- High growth differential with peers: Historically, MphasiS has lagged on revenue growth vs. peers and hence warranted lower relative valuation.- Volatility in Digital Risk revenues: The Digital Risk business has been volatile historically in a rising interest rate environment and its volatility has been a cause of concern for investors.- Uncertainty around DXC channel outlook: The DXC channel used to contribute \(>25\%\) of revenues (as of December 2019) but that share was just \(2.4\%\) of revenues in 1QF26). The channel has struggled to keep up with even the minimum revenue commitment that was given by DXC to MphasiS over a period of time.- High client concentration: Higher client concentration in top 10 accounts affects the revenue profile disproportionately in an uncertain macro environment.- Risk of promoters selling out: We think anticipation of such an event does create an overhang on the stock.
What has changed now? We think the majority of the risks outlined above have already played out.

- MphasiS's revenue growth rates could converge with mid-cap peers, unlike in the past (when its revenue growth was slower than peers).- Digital Risk revenue appears to have bottomed out with potential rate cuts on the horizon.- DXC as a channel has become immaterial for MphasiS.- Top 10 client concentration remains high relative to other mid-caps, but has come down on an absolute basis over the past three years following multiple client-specific issues.- A promoter stake sale remains a potential overhang, but we see fundamentals overtaking that technical factor. Over the longer term, we see any potential stake sale as a clearing event, which could lead to a re-rating for MphasiS, as it did for Coforge.

Case study vs. CoforgeWe think that private equity promoters selling their stake, combined with growth expansion, led to strong stock price performance for another Indian tech company, Coforge, in 2023. We think a similar thing could play out for MphasiS, given that its growth is expanding, even though full sale of promoter stake could be some time away, assuming 6- 7 years of holding period since 2021. (Typically private equity funds have a 10- year fund life, within which holding period for a particular asset is 6- 7 years.)
Exhibit 33: Coforge Stock Price Performance: Promoter stake sale and growth acceleration led to significant stock price performance
Source: Company Data, Morgan Stanley Research.

Case Study vs. LTIMindtreeOn a relative P/E basis, MBFL has traded at an average discount of 17% to LTIM over the past five years and at best at a premium of 12% over that period. However, during this time, it lagged on growth vs. LTIM. We see this changing, as we expect MBFL to generate stronger revenue growth vs. LTIM over F25- 27, which we think could lead the stock to trade at a premium to LTIM.

Revenue growth momentum accelerates sharply with margins expanding to the top end of the margin guidance range, OCF to PAT ratio of \(90\%\) and implied FCF margins of \(9.1\%\) .

1. MphasiS further accelerates addition to the qualified deal pipeline funnel, consistently achieves strong pipeline conversion to TCV (US\$750mn+ deal TCV every quarter), and TCV conversion to revenue improves with no client-specific issues. We also expect consistent rate cuts to provide tailwinds to growth in the DR business and clock revenues higher than the previous peak of US\$75mn. 
2. MphasiS is able to expand margins as strong revenue growth provides operating leverage.
Revenue growth momentum accelerates with slight margin expansion, OCF to PAT ratio of \(85\%\) and implied FCF margins of \(8.4\%\) .

1. MphasiS sustains its qualified deal pipeline funnel, continues to convert pipeline to TCV (US\$450mn+ deal TCV every quarter), and TCV conversion to revenue remains healthy with no client-specific issues. We expect some benefit of rate cuts to provide tailwinds to growth in the DR business, but this remains lower than the previous peak of US\$75mn.
2. MphasiS could get some benefit on margins from operating leverage.
Revenue growth momentum accelerates with slight margin expansion, OCF to PAT ratio of \(80\%\) and implied FCF margins of \(7.3\%\) .

1. MphasiS sustains its qualified deal pipeline funnel, but pipeline conversion to TCV slows down (US\(300mn+ deal TCV every quarter), and TCV conversion to revenue moderates. We do not expect the benefit of rate cuts to flow in the DR business and the revenue run-rate remains at current levels.  
2. MphasiS could show moderation in margins from continued investment in the business.

Our EPS estimates are largely similar to consensus; however, we have much stronger conviction in revenue growth rates for MphasiS than consensus, even though our margin assumptions are lower. We think consensus is underestimating the revenue growth potential despite delivery on pipeline and deal wins. We expect above- consensus revenue growth assumptions to also lead to a re- rating, thereby providing strong returns.
